org.ndnx.ndn.impl
Class NDNStats

java.lang.Object
  org.ndnx.ndn.impl.NDNStats
Direct Known Subclasses:
NDNStats.NDNEnumStats
public abstract class NDNStats
extends Object

This is the base class for performance counters. It is the public API that a user would access to check or display performance counters. A class that counts statistics should implement NDNStatistics. A typical usage is illustrated in ExampleClassWithStatistics at the end of this module. By using the helper class NDNEnumStats, a class with statistics only needs to define an enum of the stats it will use, and create a NDNEnumStats member with reference to that Enum. Usage example is also shown in org.ndnx.ndn.test.impl.NDNStatsTest.java The high-level abstractions are NDNStats and NDNStatistics. A typical user would only deal with those two things. The mid-level abstractions are NDNEnumStats and IStatsEnum. These are for the developer of a class that uses NDNStats. The developer could, of course, do any implementation that implements NDNStatistics. The NDNEnumStats abstraction is to simplify the process so the developer only needs to define an Enum of the counters they want to use, and pass that to NDNEnumStats. The Enum must implement IStatsEnum. After that, the usage is very simple and automagically gives the NDNStats object needed by the NDNStatistics interface. The interface NDNCategoriezedStatistics is for modules that keep statistics in several cateogries (e.g. for each ContentName you express an interest for). Added support for an "averaging" counter. This will track the sum, sum^2, and count so one can get an average and standard deviation. Basically, there's a simple "long" counter and an "averaging counter" for each Enum, so you could use the normal "increment(item)" or the new "addSample(item, value)" calls on any of the Enums. If you call addSample(item, value), then the item "item" will be tagged as an averaging stat and the toString() method will format it as such. Might want to add an EWMA type counter too. I think we'll want to expand the IStatsEnum to make it take a counter type argument.
